82D3BC8F8B06497F8C9D647E06D11B5B.description: Use stories as an inspiration for dramatic expression

D4C462CD489144CB97DCED53B8BAB1C5.description: Examine how drama can be used to express topics or themes that are important to individuals or cultures

C4D2688F6567498DBA8737EF6B8969C6.description: Express how drama is valued in one's life and culture

AAED028A819147C9A44EE921E578747D.description: Drama in New France reflected a combination of culture and traditions that served different purposes for the people who lived there

6B83654786CF4D0C8D446A25B2C9E690.description: The cultures of ancient Rome had an influence on modern-day drama and theatre

111179D84F91412A9678EB808FBF5925.description: Drama in ancient Rome reflected cultural beliefs and history

CF07BF01D76F45ABB9906E4A4156C55D.description: An artistic community is a venue for artistic expression within various cultures

B1704515133F40FFA91E8B8EF4494A05.description: Drama was valued differently across cultures throughout history.

693D36A254024FF0B0A76D6304CA440C.description: Theatre in New France was primarily performed by community members to provide entertainment and to celebrate the establishment of the French community

AEE68750998147FD8EFB625BCD060800.description: The performance of The Theatre of Neptune took place on barges and canoes in Port Royal, and depicted French exploration and expeditions to Acadia

B818F1D1332548B4B6276E3C08FA3C30.description: The Theatre of Neptune, by Marc Lescarbot in 1606, is considered one of Canada's first formal European plays that incorporated music, including trumpets, cannons, and choral singing.

A7003E697F0A474381FC85686518158E.description: Protocols related to how or with whom stories are shared were part of First Nations culture in New France and continue to hold significant importance today.

58CB24F7849642108DB911372829D6AC.description: First Nations storytelling in New France reflected traditions and beliefs that continue to be honoured and celebrated today by First Nations, MÃ©tis, and Inuit

690C3C6FD31A445BBB17EF9551E59514.description: Storytelling and ceremony were significant aspects of First Nations culture for hundreds of years before the arrival of the Europeans

5BF0D505794A44F5887FB3CD16022965.description: Mime emerged during Roman theatre as a way to interact with the chorus using dance and gestures.

CDB25E930FBC4DE48F62391869F35D9A.description: Roman pantomime is a dramatic story told without words and characterized by the use of gestures, beautiful costumes, and masks

F7C70882BE364E298CC59E3568E4576B.description: In ancient Rome, tragedies became less popular as people enjoyed and preferred the entertainment value of a comedy

CA4CBCB2B01145C9970EA9ADC44AD36B.description: A stock character represents a certain type of person or stereotype, such as a brave hero or a clumsy waiter

46255FDA50424D31B1A70DAE6C66FB9C.description: Roman theatre was well known for using stock characters and comedy, which led to the later development of clowning

C5F6B0CDF80C4A43BE2387F34D81A40F.description: Theatre in the round was a type of staging used in Greek and Roman theatre that provided enhanced sound and sightlines for an audience, as seen in the Colosseum

19FC9D5D3689487491AAFC78FA4300E1.description: Nearly all Roman plays, including the costumes used, were imitations or similar representations of Greek comedies and tragedies

65425C3E40264EE6A93093DCAD239F63.description: Stories about gods and goddesses (mythology) in ancient Rome were commonly expressed through drama

D3066E71FB6449A8962D77D5AD83D843.description: Theatre and drama in ancient Rome was valued for its ability to entertain

D8D859F5C55941A5B0A2BBF3A8584EA3.description: Dramatic forms that originated from various cultures in the past continue to be used and valued today.

43FA8DBE1E4D4381B6F6DFBF676B8F6D.description: The topics or themes expressed through drama may have a particular significance to the culture, time, and place in which they are expressed.

8A4C97A872914000B4BCABA9D635181A.description: Artistic protocols and etiquette may change based on the community, culture, presentation, and location of a performance

6CC27A1130E9447780BE6A591B2CEA0E.description: Using vocabulary related to drama can contribute to discussions about drama.

0BFD258CA85D4CFAB57386396D026FD4.description: From historical times to today, cultures may have valued drama for cultural expression, entertainment, and education

3301FF6C56DC4661835E6C45C440F281.description: Students relate how cultures of the past and present contribute to dramatic expression

5539088A0DA84ED1968F30F52F59A478.description: Appreciation: Recognizing beauty, goodness, and truth in drama can be developed by understanding the complexity and richness of great dramatic works, the artists who create and perform them, and the historical and cultural contexts from which they originate

7FCA9C77812E496CB9AA792439B5A396.description: Experiment with various ways to use the voice to perform a message in and out of character

D1E7791C96B64BE3A323225E02AA1262.description: Explain the reason for making specific artistic choices.

A02E11BF809A49CFA69E278E30EC2793.description: Make informed artistic choices to share a message through drama

F4B21EDE78AA4C499D02BA4A61F510F4.description: Messages can represent what an artist means to communicate through dramatizations

A6CE224503044D538F7382F532A86EB4.description: An audience receives and interprets messages communicated through dramatic expression

752A51AC61C642F9AA29644B3700C041.description: A message is at the centre of communication in drama

99217619884A4D66B877F4A2A38C4982.description: A single message can be expressed in numerous ways by applying artistic choices

8727072A21364067BC0BEDA60731361A.description: Artists intentionally choose specific ways to effectively share a message

272A867DF2D9423F84306B9EF77D4A8F.description: Circle formations are found in drama and storytelling across various cultures of the world

5C9E7DC2CD1C421DBEE21BCDFB3E4E69.description: The circle is a symbol that can communicate messages in drama, including unity

7BD9CF9D14C54416A2CD9D28C08E0102.description: Messages expressed through drama are clear when rehearsed and performed with energy, appropriate volume, and expressivity

8606399F3457441B9EDF13B70476D1E4.description: A performer's message can be refined for future performances when feedback is considered

189C0AB2117D4270B146E69EC4AF00B3.description: A message in drama can be developed and clarified with the help of creative processes, including generating ideas problem solving reflection giving and receiving feedback refinement rehearsal

ED5363C3FBE84AD88894FE7CA2223F23.description: A message in drama can represent a variety of themes or subjects, including ideas, culture, and events

BFC2A8AD3B3D4CFDAA690266C8B955FA.description: Messages can evoke different responses from an audience based on their beliefs, preferences, and feelings

1DCDB70EEE6348BEA828AA368BF32B3E.description: Messages can be created for an intended audience and may have topics or themes that can be sensitive to some viewers

0527FE51348F4DA2BC98754FA40E2E2B.description: Speaking clearly and with ease contributes to effectively sharing a message

1E9E1FA4B0E04FEC82DA8CBC16DF4443.description: Costumes and props can contribute to the creation of a message when used with intention

6FCB81E37F2D45189488182D5D61BFB0.description: A character's message can be communicated through artistic choices related to the voice and the body

46EDF9C903564E08A1474B2FD05CB388.description: A message can be structured using dramatic forms

10F4AD05A69741448604F57AADA5370D.description: Messages in drama can be created by imagination.

5886897A686F48A4A941E1663FEB5D6D.description: Students interpret how the communication of a message can be influenced by artistic choice in drama.

6CDA4FE1BBF54D88A6DFDE86E321C421.description: Creating and Presenting: Ideas can be represented dramatically through artworks that draw upon foundational knowledge

8C0459037FAB49698C4D8FD2703BE686.description: A performer's personal characteristics can be used as a starting point for character development

BA3D39CED8274A43914DB0A4169144DB.description: Character can be developed through the body

46B561391B4C4EAAADEFDBDD020250BA.description: The body is dynamic and can be used to express meaning.

12F12580FBE94E8980AB5B50B9B66500.description: Choral speech as a dramatic form can support group expression, including speaking clearly speaking with ease learning to articulate enjoyment of literature exploring the flexibility of the voice

750583215B354898BC6A21D8F4CFB200.description: Character development can be supported by other characters

E5D230EA3ABB4BCBB2FA248B5AF877A9.description: Role play can support the exploration of a character

2D2B06A53C5A4A79BEC8C5BA613CD589.description: The voice is part of the body and can be used to develop a character

347265C9FCFC44F98AB79E2A91040192.description: Body actions can convey character through facial expressions, gestures, and body movements

A8040B95AB2B448E9C8CD372C08A180A.description: Physical theatre is a dramatic form that uses body movements to tell a story.

2EF637EC148241CF8338353DE9D3832B.description: Mime is a dramatic form that uses specific movements to communicate non-verbally

541FD73F7CA44D7A9BE52D537D58511E.description: Individuals express meaning with the body in various ways.

338BCE7C08C048A889A12C380BCA5B80.description: The body can represent the material world through drama, including animals, objects, and the environment

BE0C0E05C856437092A6E0C90D2B60DF.description: Students analyze how the body can portray character in a variety of dramatic contexts.

D0120DEB178E4E898719207D4BF3E8B4.description: Foundational Elements: Drama literacy is developed through knowledge and application of dramatic processes.
